fields.headline: Crossing points
fields.bodyText: As far as I'm aware, no one has yet succeeded in doing for ferries what Expedia, Ebookers and Flynow have done for flights. In other words, you can't type in two ports, obtain a quote and book the crossing online. You'll need to do your research first - using one of the first two sites listed below - and then visit the company's own site to find timetables and complete the booking. A disappointing state of affairs. Ferry Information Service Run by the Passenger Shipping Association, this recently launched effort serves very little purpose. You can't book here and, apart from a few driving tips, a static route map and links to the members of the PSA, it's a shocking waste of time. Irishferries.com Routes: Ireland-England/ Ireland-France Apart from a couple of broken links, this is an excellent site. Visitors can take a virtual tour of all the ferries (including the world's largest car ferry, Ulysses), get a quote, and book online. Navigation is exemplary and the Frequently Asked Questions section particularly useful. Brittany Ferries Routes: Britain and Cork to France/ Britain to Spain Efficient and intelligent online booking, although the supporting information is a little thin. DFDS Seaways Routes: Harwich and Newcastle to Scandinavia, Germany and Holland A well-thought-out timetable section is let down by a confusing booking system - how do you know which fare to choose from the pull-down menu? Best used for planning your trip rather than trying to book it. Stena Line Routes: UK and Ireland to Holland and Scandinavia Look at the timetables first; if you want to book online, you'll need to register. Again, the process is not wholly clear. Seafrance Route: Dover-Calais At first glance, the Seafrance site looks rather old-fashioned - but booking turns out to be simple and easy to understand, if a little slow. Online bookings attract a £5 discount. P&O Stena Line Route: Dover-Calais Despite a few minor problems in Netscape, it's certainly worth checking the prices here; Dover-Calais is a competitive route.
